awd_titl_txt: COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH: Physiological Adaptation to Extreme Environments: Genes, Function, and Evolutionary Patterns
awd_abstract_narration:
Extreme environments allow for the investigation of life's capacity and limitations to cope with far-from-average environmental conditions. Springs rich in hydrogen sulfide represent some of the most extreme freshwater environments, because hydrogen sulfide halts energy production in animal cells. Nonetheless, some fish have colonized sulfide springs throughout the Americas, and it remains unknown how they can tolerate conditions so toxic that most other organisms perish. This project will compare closely related populations that live in adjacent sulfidic or nonsulfidic habitats to identify differences in genetic, biochemical, and physiological traits that underlie tolerance to this noxious chemical. It involves the identification of genetic differences between hydrogen sulfide-tolerant and susceptible populations, particularly in genes associated with pathways affected by hydrogen sulfide toxicity or detoxification. In addition, the tolerance and the susceptibility of fish populations will be measured in the presence or absence of hydrogen sulfide. This project will yield new insights into mechanisms underlying physiological tolerance to hydrogen sulfide and the workings of animals in the presence of physiochemical stressors. Given hydrogen sulfide's role in cellular processes and disease formation, this also has implications for biomedical applications. This project provides training opportunities in integrative biology for participants at all levels of higher education. It will also contribute to science education and public outreach through the generation of an exhibit at a local zoo and the involvement of high school teachers that will generate lesson plans implementing next generation science education standards for K-12 education in STEM fields. 

Leveraging knowledge from toxicological and biomedical studies, this project addresses hypotheses about mechanisms of physiological adaptation to naturally H2S-rich environments and focuses on components of and associated with the oxidative phosphorylation pathway (OXPHOS) in mitochondria. These components include targets of H2S toxicity as well as enzymes involved in H2S detoxification. It is predicted that focal components are modulated or modified in sulfide spring populations, such that individuals have an increased ability to withstand elevated H2S concentrations, an increased ability to detoxify H2S enzymatically, and an ability to maintain or even increase mitochondrial energy production by using H2S a substrate to fuel metabolism. Furthermore, it is anticipated that modification of OXPHOS components has occurred repeatedly across independent lineages that have colonized sulfide springs. To test these predictions, this project focuses on an established model system (Poecilia mexicana) for the investigation of H2S adaptation and has three major empirical components: (1) Characterization of transcriptional and coding variation in candidate genes by use of high-throughput sequencing techniques and subsequent validation of effects on protein concentrations and structure. (2) Quantification of functional consequences of transcriptional and coding variation for H2S detoxification and bioenergetics both in vitro and in vivo. (3) Comparison of gene sequence and expression variation across a dozen independent population pairs from sulfidic and non-sulfidic habitats to test for convergence.

por.por_cntn:
This project uncovered the genetic and physiological mechanisms that mediate adaptation to extreme environmental conditions. It focused on an abiotic environmental stressor (toxic levels of hydrogen sulfide) with clear-cut biochemical, physiological, and ecological consequences, which create strong divergent selection across environmental gradients that are highly replicable across spatially disparate sites. Ultimately, this allowed for hypothesis-driven tests of organismal responses to and evolutionary consequences of perpetual exposure to environmental stress. We found strong patterns of local adaptation that have evolved in convergence across different evolutionary lineages of the fish Pocilia mexicana. Fish from sulfide spring population can withstand toxic hydrogen sulfide, both because they have modified mitochondria that reduce hydrogen sulfide toxicity and because they can more rapidly detoxify hydrogen sulfide through enzymatic oxidation. These adaptations give sulfide spring populations significantly higher levels of tolerance to this environmental toxicant compared to closely related populations in adjacent non-sulfidic waters. Our research has also indicated that mechanisms of hydrogen sulfide adaptation did not only evolve in convergence across different lineages of Poecilia mexicana, but also among 10 other species in the fish family Poeciliidae that have colonized sulfide springs in different portions of the Neotropics. Overall, our results demonstrate that the modification of highly conserved physiological pathways associated with essential mitochondrial processes mediates tolerance to physiochemical stress. In addition, the same pathways, genes, and-in some instances-codons are implicated in hydrogen sulfide adaptation in lineages that span 40 million years of evolution. Findings from this project are highly relevant for our understanding of life in extreme environments and for the burgeoning field of H2S biology, which is fueled by sulfide’s potential role in modulating cellular processes and as a therapeutic. Our comparative analyses between closely related populations that differ in their ability to cope with disruptions of H2S homeostasis contributed to our understanding of the physiological effects and biochemical processing of H2S, with concomitant implications for the development of biomedical applications.

The project provided graduate and undergraduate students with hand-on research experiences with exposure to diverse methodologies (including genome analysis, physiological and behavioral ecology, and morphological analysis) both in the lab and in the field. In the six years (including no cost extensions), this project has supported 6 graduate students and 12 undergraduate students at KSU, 1 graduate student and 1 undergraduate student at OSU, and 5 graduate students and 13 undergraduate students at WSU. In addition, the project supported one postdoctoral researcher at KSU and a project by one postdoctoral research at WSU. We provided a collaborative work environment across institutions and countries that provides the students with the opportunity to interact with scientists outside of our group. Pre-COVID, students also had opportunities to visit Universidad Juárez Autónoma de Tabasco in Mexico to interact with faculty and students. For undergraduates, we provided research experiences customized to the needs and interests of individuals students. Teaching experiences were available to graduate students in the form of mentoring undergraduates. Mentoring was discussed in the weekly personal meetings with the graduate students, and the PIs provided the graduate students with mentoring advice relating to effective communication, project planning, quality control, and providing constructive feedback. We also provided students with training in science communication. Training was facilitated in collaboration with educators at the Sunset Zoo (Manhattan, KS) and consisted of workshops that were also open to other students and postdocs at Kansas State University. For example, graduate students at WSU and KSU participated in a Science Communication Conference and Workshop (SciComm 2019, Manhattan, KS) to hone their skills of presenting science to diverse audiences. We also created and implemented a computational bootcamp for undergraduates at Washington State University. Collectively, we have visited K-12 classrooms in the greater Manhattan (KS) area and participated in numerous Skype-A-Scientist sessions with K-12 classes. We have also presented at multiple Science on Tap/Science Café events in Manhattan and Lawrence (KS), Science After Hours in Moscow (ID/WA), participated in Science Saturdays at the local Sunset Zoo (KS), organized a Science Communication Week (KS), and Stillwater Public Library (OK) science program geared toward elementary and middle school aged children. A permanent exhibit featuring the research conducted in this project opened at Sunset Zoo on April 21, 2018, providing outreach to 80,000 annual visitors.
